html:
Look, if you're sending a solar generator to Cuba, you're not just buying backup power—you're buying sanity.

Eight-hour apagones are the new normal. Your family's fridge is sweating. The fan stopped mid-siesta. And somewhere in Havana, your tía is lighting candles like it's 1959. Jackery and Bluetti are the two names that keep coming up when people ask what actually works—but which one survives Cuban humidity, handles 110V without drama, and won't get seized at customs for being "too heavy"? That's what we're figuring out.

Solar generators aren't just camping toys anymore. For Cuban families dealing with rolling blackouts, they're the difference between spoiled food and a working refrigerator, between a dark house and lights for the kids to do homework. But here's the thing—not every "portable power station" is actually portable enough to ship, powerful enough to matter, or built to handle salt air and tropical humidity.

Both Jackery and Bluetti use LiFePO4 batteries in their newer models, which is huge. These last 3,000+ charge cycles (versus maybe 500 for older lithium-ion), handle heat better, and don't catch fire when stressed. That matters when your abuela's house hits 35°C in August.

The real questions: How much power do you actually need? Can you afford the shipping weight? And will it survive the journey—and the years after? Let's break this down by what your family actually needs.

The Quick Answer

For most Cuban households, the Bluetti AC180 hits the sweet spot—more wattage (1800W vs 1500W), faster charging, and slightly more capacity than the Jackery 1000 v2, all at the $$$$$ tier. But if you need serious power for a whole house, the Jackery Explorer 2000 v2 is the beast that can run a fridge AND a fan AND charge phones simultaneously.

A typical 8-hour blackout running fridge + fan + lights = ~2,300Wh needed

The Contenders: Jackery vs Bluetti

Six models, two brands, one goal: keeping the lights on cuando se va la corriente.

Editor's Pick for Most Families

Bluetti AC180 (1152Wh)

4.6★ (465 reviews) • $$$$$

Here's why this wins for Cuba: 1800W continuous output (2700W surge) means it can actually start a fridge compressor—something the 1500W Jackery might struggle with. The 0-80% charge in 45 minutes is clutch when power comes back briefly. Reviewers consistently mention the build quality holding up in humid conditions, and at 1152Wh, it'll run a small fridge for about 7-8 hours.

The catch: It's heavy at 37 lbs—shipping costs will hurt. But for a family that needs real power, not just phone charging, this is the one.

VERDICT: The Goldilocks choice—enough power to matter, not so heavy it's impossible to ship.

Check Price on Amazon

Head-to-Head: The 1000Wh Class

These two are the most popular mid-range options. Same price tier, similar capacity—but important differences.

Jackery Explorer 1000 v2

4.7★ (475 reviews) • $$$$$

  • ✓ 1070Wh capacity
  • ✓ 1500W output (lower)
  • ✓ 1 hour fast charge
  • ✓ Better brand recognition
  • ✗ Lower wattage for appliances
Winner

Bluetti AC180

4.6★ (465 reviews) • $$$$$

  • ✓ 1152Wh capacity (+8%)
  • ✓ 1800W output (+20%)
  • ✓ 45 min to 80% (faster)
  • ✓ 4 AC outlets vs 3
  • ✓ Better for fridge startup

The verdict: Bluetti AC180 wins this matchup. That extra 300W of output is the difference between "maybe it'll start the fridge" and "definitely will." Same price tier, more capability.

For Serious Power Needs: The 2000Wh Beast

If your family has a larger fridge, needs to run multiple fans, or just wants to weather 12+ hour blackouts—this is the one.

Best for Large Households

Jackery Explorer 2000 v2

4.7★ (475 reviews) • $$$$$

Double the capacity (2042Wh), 2200W output, and LiFePO4 chemistry that'll last 10+ years. This thing can run a medium fridge for 13-14 hours straight, or power the whole house during a typical apagón. Reviewers rave about the build quality and the fact that it handles Cuban-style voltage fluctuations without flinching.

Reality check: It weighs 61 lbs. Shipping to Cuba will cost almost as much as a second unit. But for a family that's serious about power independence, this is the investment that pays off.

VERDICT: The "never worry about blackouts again" option. Heavy, expensive, worth it.

Check Price on Amazon

The 2025 Wildcard: Bluetti Elite 100 V2

Brand New 2025

Bluetti Elite 100 V2 (1024Wh)

4.5★ (New - Limited Reviews) • $$$$$

This just dropped and it's intriguing: 35% smaller than previous models with the same capacity, 4 AC outlets at 1800W (3600W surge), and a design that screams "I was made for tight spaces." The compact size could be a game-changer for shipping costs.

The catch: Almost no reviews yet. We're seeing great specs on paper, but no long-term durability data. If you're willing to be an early adopter, this could be the smartest buy of 2025. If you want proven reliability, stick with the AC180.

VERDICT: High potential, but wait for reviews unless you like living on the edge.

Check Price on Amazon →

Budget-Friendlier Options (Still $$$$$, But Lower End)

Not everyone needs 1000+ watts. For phone charging, lights, and small fans, these smaller units make sense—and they're way easier to ship.

Best Value

Bluetti AC50B (448Wh)

4.6★ (465 reviews) • $$$$$

The sweet spot for smaller households. 700W output (1000W with power lifting) handles fans and lights easily. LiFePO4 battery, 0-80% in 45 minutes. At ~15 lbs, shipping is actually reasonable. Won't run a fridge, but perfect for the essentials.

VERDICT: Best bang-for-buck if you don't need fridge power.

Check Price →

Jackery Explorer 300

4.6★ (465 reviews)

The ultra-portable option at 293Wh. Only 7 lbs—ship it in a suitcase. Good for phones, tablets, LED lights. Not LiFePO4 though, so shorter lifespan.

VERDICT: Phone charging + lights only.

Check Price →

Compare Them Side-by-Side

⚠️ Shipping Reality Check

These units are HEAVY. Before you click buy, check shipping costs to Cuba—they can add 30-50% to the total price. The Jackery 2000 v2 at 61 lbs might cost $200+ just to ship. The Bluetti AC50B at 15 lbs? Much more reasonable.

What Actually Matters for Cuba

✓ Voltage Compatibility

All these units output 110V AC—perfect for Cuba. No adapters needed, no transformer drama.

✓ LiFePO4 Battery

Handles heat better than lithium-ion. Critical for Cuban summers. All models except the Jackery 300 have this.

✓ Solar Ready

All accept solar panel input. Buy panels separately—they're lighter and easier to ship in pieces.

⚠️ Customs Consideration

Large batteries can trigger extra scrutiny. Keep documentation. Units under 1000Wh tend to pass easier.

The Bottom Line

Bluetti edges out Jackery in this matchup—more wattage per dollar, faster charging, and the AC180 specifically hits the sweet spot for Cuban households dealing with regular apagones. The Jackery 2000 v2 is the exception if you need maximum capacity and don't mind the shipping weight.

Whatever you choose, you're giving your family something priceless: the ability to keep food cold, fans spinning, and phones charged when the grid goes dark. That's not just convenience—that's peace of mind.
